verb.description: (of an object, especially a ball) move quickly up, back, or away from a surface after hitting it; rebound (once or repeatedly)
examples: the ball bounced away and he chased it
he was bouncing the ball against the wall
the ball bounced off the rim

verb.description: (of a person) jump repeatedly up and down, typically on something springy.
examples: bouncing up and down on the mattress

verb.description: (of a check) be returned by a bank when there are insufficient funds to meet it.
Eject (a troublemaker) forcibly from a nightclub or similar establishment.

noun.description: A rebound of a ball or other object.
examples: a bad bounce caused the ball to get away from the second baseman

noun.description: An act of jumping or an instance of being moved up and down.
examples: every bounce of the truck brought them into fresh contact
a bounce on your knee or a cuddle and pat on the back

phrases: Some days she is bouncing off the walls because she took too many pills; the next all she can do is complain because she took too few.
My students were bouncing off the walls by the time I dismissed them for Christmas break on the 17th of December.
I was bouncing off the walls, being very, very energetic.
If it weren't so early, you'd be bouncing off the walls, and you know it!
I'm ecstatic, I haven't stopped talking about it and I'm just bouncing off the walls at the moment, said Chris.
origin: Middle English bunsen beat, thump, perhaps imitative, or from Low German bunsen beat, Dutch bons a thump.
